title: 109_hr1598
content: The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" improves veterans' benefits for former prisoners of war. The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" repeals the minimum period of internment for presumption of service connection for certain diseases under title 38, United States Code. The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" repeals the minimum period of internment for presumption of service connection for certain diseases under title 38, United States Code. It further amends section 1112(b) by adding additional diseases presumed to be service connected. The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" repeals the minimum internment period for presumption of service connection for certain diseases under title 38, United States Code. It adds heart disease, stroke, diabetes (type 2), and osteoporosis to the list of additional diseases presumed to be service connected. Administrative determination of presumption of service connection for these diseases is authorized under section 1112 of title 38, United States Code. The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" allows for administrative determination of presumption of service connection for additional diseases related to being a prisoner of war under section 1112 of title 38, United States Code. The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" allows for presumption of service connection for diseases associated with being a prisoner of war based on sound medical and scientific evidence. The Secretary will prescribe regulations for diseases with a positive association with the experience of being a prisoner of war. The Secretary will consider recommendations from the Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War and other medical information to determine service connection for diseases related to being a prisoner of war. Study results must be statistically significant, replicable, and peer-reviewed. The Secretary evaluates studies for service connection determinations, considering statistical significance, replicability, and peer review. An association between a disease and being a prisoner of war is deemed positive if credible evidence supports it. Recommendations from the Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War are reviewed within 60 days for presumptions of service connection. The Secretary evaluates studies for service connection determinations based on statistical significance, replicability, and peer review. If credible evidence supports an association between a disease and being a prisoner of war, the Secretary will review recommendations from the Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War within 60 days to establish a presumption of service connection for that disease. If warranted, proposed regulations will be issued within 60 days. The Secretary will issue proposed regulations within 60 days if a presumption of service connection is warranted for a disease. If not warranted, a notice will be published in the Federal Register with an explanation. The Secretary will publish a notice in the Federal Register with an explanation of the scientific basis for a determination regarding service connection for a disease. If a presumption is not warranted, proposed regulations removing the presumption will be issued within 60 days, with final regulations to follow within 90 days. The Secretary will issue final regulations within 90 days of proposing them. If a disease is removed from regulations, veterans and survivors will still receive compensation based on the previous presumption. Veterans and survivors will continue to receive compensation for diseases even after they are removed from regulations, based on the previous presumption. The Secretary will consult with the Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War when implementing this subsection. The Secretary will consult with the Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War when implementing compensation changes for veterans and survivors, as specified in the regulations.
